questions.text: A 6 year old boy presents with ear pain, and hearing loss for the past 2 days. He also has a recent history of the common cold. Otoscopy shows a retracted tympanic membrane with fluid. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa

options.label: C
options.text: Biofilm formation in the middle ear

questions.text: A 4 year old girl presents with ear pain, fever, and a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, her tympanic membrane is red and bulging. What is the most likely route of infection for her condition?
questions.explanation:
ASOM Etiology

Common Predisposing Factors

Bacterial Causes
  • Frequent colds and upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Tonsil and adenoid infections.
  • Chronic nasal conditions like rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Allergies involving the nasal passages.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours or nasal packing for epistaxis (nosebleeds).
  • Cleft palate
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (30% of cases)
  • Haemophilus influenza (20%)
  • Moraxella catarrhalis (12%)
  • Occasionally, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa also contribute.

questions.text: A 6 year old with severe earache and fever following an upper respiratory infection presents with a bulging, red tympanic membrane and a yellowish spot. What stage of ASOM is this?
questions.explanation:
Stages of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)

Stages

Feature & Symptoms

Signs

Stage of Tubal Occlusion (Option A ruled out)
  • The Eustachian tube becomes blocked due to inflammation and increased blood flow, particularly at the nasopharyngeal end.
  • Mild hearing loss and earache. Usually, no fever is present.
  • Eardrum retraction, the handle of the malleus becomes horizontal, prominent lateral process of the malleus, and reduced light reflex.

Stage of Exudation (Presuppuration) (Option B ruled out)
  • If the Eustachian tube blockage continues, pyogenic bacteria invade the middle ear, leading to inflammation and fluid accumulation.
  • Symptoms worsen, with significant earache that may disrupt sleep. Hearing loss and tinnitus may occur.
  • Redness initially on the pars tensa, followed by visible blood vessels along the malleus handle and the eardrum's periphery creating a "cartwheel" appearance.

Stage of Suppuration (Option C)
  • Pus forms in the middle ear causing the eardrum to bulge outward due to the pressure.
  • Excruciating earache, increased hearing loss, high fever (up to 102°F-103°F), vomiting, and possible convulsions.
  • A red, bulging eardrum with obscured landmarks, a hidden malleus handle, and a yellow spot indicating potential eardrum rupture.

Stage of Resolution (Option D ruled out)
  • The eardrum ruptures spontaneously, releasing pus and alleviating pressure.
  • Relief from earache and fever as the inflammatory process subsides. Symptoms improve with pus drainage.
  • Blood-tinged discharge initially, becoming mucopurulent.
  • A small perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant of the pars tensa is usually visible.
  • The eardrum's redness decreases and its landmarks become visible.

Stage of Complications
  • In severe cases, the infection may spread beyond the middle ear, leading to serious complications.
  • Potential complications include acute mastoiditis, subperiosteal abscess, facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, petrositis, extradural abscess, meningitis, brain abscess, and lateral sinus thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with severe earache, fever, and discharge from her right ear for 3 days. On examination, her tympanic membrane appears bulging and red. What is the most appropriate initial management for this child?
questions.explanation:
Antibiotics

  

Supportive Management

  

Myringotomy
  • Indications: All cases with fever and severe earache.
  • First-line:
    • Ampicillin: 50 mg/kg/day in four divided doses.
    • Amoxicillin: 40 mg/kg/day in three divided doses.
  • Penicillin-allergic alternatives: Cefaclor, Co-trimoxazole, or Erythromycin.
  • For β-lactamase-producing H. influenzae or M. catarrhalis: Amoxicillin-clavulanate, Cefuroxime axetil, or Cefixime.
  • Duration: Minimum of 10 days until tympanic membrane and hearing normalize.
  • Decongestant Nasal Drops:
    • Ephedrine: 1% (adults), 0.5% (children).
    • Oxymetazoline (Nasivion) or Xylometazoline (Otrivin) to reduce Eustachian tube edema.
  • Oral Nasal Decongestants:
    • Pseudoephedrine: 30 mg twice daily.
    • Combination with antihistaminic: Triominic for children to avoid nasal drops.
  • Analgesics and Antipyretics:
    • Paracetamol: Pain relief and fever reduction.
    • Ibuprofen syrup: Alternative for pain and fever.
  • Ear Toilet:
    • Dry mop discharge with sterile cotton buds.
    • Insert antibiotic-moistened wick if discharge persists.
  • Dry Local Heat:
    • Pain relief.
  • Indications:
    • Bulging drum with acute pain.
    • Incomplete resolution despite antibiotics (persistent conductive hearing loss).
    • Persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks (chronic otitis media).
  • Follow-up: Monitor until the tympanic membrane normalizes and conductive hearing loss resolves.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of persistent hearing loss over the past 6 months. His parents report that he seems to be asking for the TV to be louder and often complains of a feeling of fullness in his ears. An otoscopic examination reveals a dull, opaque tympanic membrane with decreased mobility in both ears. What is the most likely underlying cause of this child's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Malfunctioning of Eustachian tube

Allergy

Unresolved otitis media

Viral infections
  • Adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Chronic tonsillitis: Enlarged tonsils obstruct the soft palate and affect Eustachian tube function.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours: Benign or malignant, especially in adults with unilateral serous otitis media.
  • Palatal defects: e.g., cleft palate, palatal paralysis.
  • Down's syndrome.

Seasonal or perennial allergies obstruct the Eustachian tube and increase middle ear mucosal secretions.

Inadequate antibiotic therapy can lead to persistent, low-grade infection, stimulating more mucous production and increasing goblet cells.


Adenoviruses and rhinoviruses can invade the middle ear mucosa, leading to increased secretory activity.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of recurrent nasal obstruction and unilateral ear fullness. On examination, there is serous otitis media in the right ear. What is the most likely cause of this child's condition?

A 6 year old child presents with a history of mild hearing loss, difficulty following conversations, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. On examination, the tympanic membrane appears dull and retracted, with visible fluid levels behind it. Which of the following tuning fork test results is most likely to be observed in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the unaffected ear

options.label: B
options.text: Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the affected ear

options.label: C
options.text: Positive Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the affected ear

options.label: D
options.text: Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the unaffected ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the affected ear
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Symptoms
  • Hearing Loss: Conductive, mild to moderate (20-40 dB), gradual onset, may fluctuate; children may not complain, but parents may notice difficulties in hearing.
  • Delayed/Defective Speech
  • Mild Earaches
  • Fullness in Ear.

Signs

  • Tympanic Membrane Appearance: Dull, opaque, possibly yellow, grey, or bluish; absence of the usual light reflex.
  • Visible Fluid/Bubbles: Air-fluid levels or bubbles visible behind the eardrum.
  • Retracted Tympanic Membrane: Negative middle ear pressure causing eardrum retraction, with the malleus handle appearing shortened or horizontal.
  • Reduced Tympanic Membrane Mobility.

Test

Description

Rinne Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), bone conduction is better than air conduction (negative Rinne test).

Weber Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the sound is louder in the affected ear when the tuning fork is placed on the forehead.

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for a similar duration when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals plugged) in conductive hearing loss (SOM). (Bone conduction not impaired)

Schwabach's Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals not plugged).

Pneumatic Otoscopy
  • Visualizes eardrum movement with air pressure changes; reduced/absent movement indicates fluid presence.

Impedance audiometry
  • Measures eardrum movement; typically shows a flat/dome-shaped curve with negative pressure, indicating reduced compliance.

Audiometry
  • Conductive hearing loss (20-40 dB).
  • Sometimes, associated sensorineural hearing loss (d/t fluid on the round window membrane.

X-ray/CT Scan of Temporal Bone
  • May show mastoid air cell clouding due to fluid

questions.text: Which of the following tympanometry curves corresponds to Serous Otitis Media?

A 5 year old child diagnosed with serous otitis media has persistent middle ear fluid despite medical treatment and even myringotomy and fluid aspiration. Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Details

Decongestants

Topical or systemic decongestants relieve eustachian tube oedema.

Antiallergic Measures

Use of antihistamines or steroids; allergen avoidance or desensitisation if possible.

Antibiotics

Useful for treating upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media. (Option C ruled out)

Middle Ear Aeration

Techniques include the Valsalva manoeuvre, politzerization, eustachian tube catheterization, insufflation, and chewing gum to open the tube.

Procedure

Details

Myringotomy and Aspiration of Fluid

An incision in the tympanic membrane to aspirate fluid; thick mucus may require saline or mucolytic agents like chymotrypsin solution.

Grommet Insertion

If fluid recurs after myringotomy and aspiration, a grommet is inserted for continued middle ear aeration; remains in place for weeks or months.

Tympanotomy or Cortical Mastoidectomy

Required for removing loculated thick fluid or other pathologies like cholesterol granuloma.

Surgical Treatment of Causative Factor

Procedures like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and/or maxillary antra washout may be needed, typically performed during myringotomy.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presents with a history of ear discomfort and hearing loss. On examination, the tympanic membrane is dull and retracted, with visible air-fluid levels behind it. The child has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)

Serous Otitis Media (SOM)

Definition

Acute inflammation of the middle ear.

Accumulation of non-purulent fluid in the middle ear; also called Otitis Media with Effusion (OME).

Cause

Mainly bacterial (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis).

Eustachian tube dysfunction due to respiratory infections, allergies, or enlarged adenoids; also can be due to unresolved AOM or viral infections.

Symptoms

Rapid onset of pain, red/bulging tympanic membrane, fever, systemic symptoms.

Often subtle: hearing loss (conductive), mild earaches, feeling of fullness, delayed speech.

Discharge

Purulent (contains pus).

Non-purulent fluid.

Key Distinctions

Presence of Pus: ASOM has purulent discharge.

Presence of Fluid: SOM has non-purulent fluid.

Symptom Severity: ASOM has severe, rapid-onset symptoms.

Symptom Severity: SOM has more subtle, gradual symptoms.

Treatment

Requires antibiotics for bacterial infection.

May involve decongestants, antihistamines, and addressing underlying causes; antibiotics are not typically needed.
